What disease is anal itching? Causes, symptoms and prevention

Anal itching is a common unpleasant symptom, stemming from many different causes. In most cases, effectiveness can be improved by taking medication and changing daily lifestyle. However, to minimize some unwanted medical problems, as soon as patients notice any unusual signs, they should immediately contact their doctor to find effective solutions.

What disease is anal itching?
Anal itching is a condition in which the skin in or around the anus becomes irritated, leading to uncomfortable itching. In most cases, it is usually a sign that this area is infected. The intensity of itching and the degree of inflammation tend to increase when the anus is directly damaged by scratching or exposure to moisture. In case the itching progresses intensely and appears with symptoms of pain and burning, the patient may not be able to bear it.(1)
Anal itching is divided into two main types, including:
Primary anal itching: This type is often the most common, with no clear cause.; Secondary anal itching: This type comes from many different causes such as infection, contact dermatitis...

Causes of anal itching
Anal itching occurs due to many different reasons, typically including: (2)
1. Pinworm infection
Pinworms are parasites with a small body size, white or light gray color, and grow and reproduce based on nutrients taken from the host. The main habitat is the patient's intestines and rectum, laying eggs around the anus at night, causing itching. Pinworms enter the digestive tract through dirty food or unsanitary utensils. This condition occurs most commonly in children.
2. Due to anal fistula
Anal fistulas are tears in the mucosa or anal canal, causing fluid to flow out, irritating the skin, leading to pain and itching. The leading cause of this condition is trauma, including: constipation, diarrhea for long periods of time, anal sex... In addition, cancer, Crohn's disease... are also factors may increase the risk of anal fistula.
3. Due to hemorrhoids
Hemorrhoids are swollen veins that form outside or inside the anus and rectum, causing a burning and itching sensation. External hemorrhoids (large hemorrhoids outside the anus) can make cleaning after bowel movements difficult. Internal hemorrhoids (hemorrhoids inside the rectum) can even lead to bleeding, fecal incontinence or incontinence. All of these cases irritate the skin, causing the anus to itch.
4. Due to allergy to medicine
Antibiotics are often used to treat infections, but in many cases they can kill beneficial bacteria in the intestines. At this time, the natural balance is lost, leading to diarrhea. In some cases, yeast infections also occur due to the use of antibiotics. From there, the skin in the anus is easily irritated, leading to uncomfortable itching and burning.
5. Due to Candida fungal infection
Candida fungi often live in the digestive tract, accumulate in the intestines and then move to the anal canal causing yeast infections. This type of parasite grows and develops in a humid environment, some favorable conditions include:
The weather is hot and humid; Wear tight clothes; Hygiene is not guaranteed; Sweating too much.
People susceptible to Candida infection include:
Pregnant women.; People who are overweight or obese; The patient is taking antibiotics; People with weakened immune systems due to diabetes or taking immunosuppressant drugs.; Pregnant .
6. Due to sexual diseases
Some sexually transmitted diseases can also cause anal itching, such as herpes, warts, gonorrhea... Among them, warts are the most common factor, caused by the HPV virus. This is a sexually transmitted disease that develops in and around the anus and can then spread to the genitals. If this condition is not treated early, there is a risk of more acne appearing, and in the long term it can easily lead to anal cancer.
7. Hygiene habits
The habit of not cleaning thoroughly after defecation can cause anal itching due to remaining waste. Therefore, it is better to use wet, odorless, gentle paper to wipe first, then clean again with dry, soft paper. In addition, some bad habits such as using hot water, soap, scented spray, wiping too hard... can also make itching worse. The reason is that anal skin is very sensitive, the protective barrier is easily destroyed, leading to irritation.
8. Eating habits
Soft drinks can cause the anal muscles to loosen, causing stool to leak out, causing itching. In addition, some other foods and drinks also cause similar irritation, including:
Coffee.; Tea.; Chocolate.; Spicy food.; Citrus fruits.; Tomato.; Butter, milk.
9. Psoriasis
Psoriasis often appears in areas of the skin that are not exposed to the sun. This can also be the cause of anal itching, redness but no scabs. The itching is often very intense, accompanied by a burning pain during defecation. Similarly, eczema is also a common cause, and increased sebum secretion can also be a factor causing itching in the anus.
10. Other causes
Anal sphincter laxity – frequent fecal leakage causes anal itching.; Diabetes.; Early stage leukemia; Warts.; Women in menopause.; Using unsafe underwear can cause anal irritation; Medical problems: type 2 diabetes, leukemia, lymphoma, kidney failure, liver disease, hyperthyroidism, anemia...; Psychological anxiety and stress.(5)

Recognize the symptoms of anal itching
Itching in the anus is easy to recognize by some typical symptoms as follows:(4)
Itching in anal area; Anal pain; Burning in anal area; Scratches appear on the anus; The skin around the anus is abnormally thickened; Anal itching occurs during defecation; Anal itching with genital itching; In some cases, anal itching is accompanied by blood.

How to diagnose anal itching?
To diagnose anal itching, your doctor will conduct a number of tests to determine the exact cause. Issues that patients may need detailed answers to include:
Time when itchy symptoms appear.; Some factors are suspected to lead to the feeling of itching.; Recent living and eating habits...; Medical history (hemorrhoids, diabetes), previous surgery; Symptoms of uncontrolled urination or defecation (if any).
Next, the patient can also have a digital rectal examination to get the most accurate results. With this method, the doctor will put a glove on one finger (combined with lubrication), then pass it through the anus into the rectum. Some problems that can be identified include: hemorrhoids, rectal bleeding, ulcers... In many cases, the doctor may also order other tests such as:
Pinworm test.; Use a cotton swab to check for infection.; Biopsy.; Blood tests.

How to treat anal itching?
How to treat anal itching will depend on the cause. For primary anal itching, the simple way to improve it is to clean thoroughly after defecation, dry it or apply baby powder (consult your doctor before using). In secondary cases, patients need to apply some of the following treatment solutions: (3)
Use over-the-counter (OTC) Hydrocortisone, apply it to the itchy area 2-3 times a day.; Use Capsaicin cream for chronic itching.; Use of antibiotics and antifungals; Methylene injection (anal tattoo) to help relieve pain and itching.; Anal Plasma projection.; While you are having anal itching, you should not use soap or gynecological wash to clean this area, instead you should only use warm water.

How to prevent anal itching
Anal itching can be effectively prevented by building reasonable and healthy daily eating, living, hygiene... habits. As follows:
Use toilet paper containing natural, odorless ingredients: Many types of toilet paper contain dyes and scents that can irritate the skin when used, leading to itching in the anal area.; Use toilet paper containing natural, odorless ingredients: Many types of toilet paper contain dyes and scents that can irritate the skin when used, leading to itching in the anal area.
Avoid using strong soaps and deodorants: These are all products that contain irritating ingredients, easily causing the anus to become itchy and uncomfortable.; Avoid using strong soaps and deodorants: These are all products that contain irritating ingredients, easily causing the anus to become itchy and uncomfortable.
Prioritize wearing cotton underwear with good moisture absorption ability: This helps the anal area stay dry, avoiding moisture and causing irritation. In addition, the habit of using well-fitting underwear, changing it regularly... is also a useful prevention method.; Prioritize wearing cotton underwear with good moisture absorption ability: This helps the anal area stay dry, avoiding moisture and causing irritation. In addition, the habit of using well-fitting underwear, changing it regularly... is also a useful prevention method.
Avoid certain foods and drinks that can cause itching in the anal area such as: milk, carbonated drinks, caffeine, vegetarian foods, containing a lot of acid...; Avoid certain foods and drinks that can cause itching in the anal area such as: milk, carbonated drinks, caffeine, vegetarian foods, containing a lot of acid...
Add plenty of fiber through daily meals, including: fruits, green vegetables, cereals... to avoid constipation and diarrhea.; Add plenty of fiber through daily meals, including: fruits, green vegetables, cereals... to avoid constipation and diarrhea.
Gentle hygiene: Clean hygiene habits after defecation will help effectively prevent common anal itching symptoms, especially using only clean water, gentle soap and soft towels to avoid irritation. ; Gentle hygiene: Clean hygiene habits after defecation will help effectively prevent common anal itching symptoms, especially using only clean water, gentle soap and soft towels to avoid irritation.

Frequently asked questions about anal itching
1. Is anal itching dangerous?
In many cases, anal itching is not dangerous and can be effectively improved by regular hygiene, changing eating and living habits and using medication. However, after a while, if the symptoms do not improve or even become worse, the patient should proactively contact a doctor for timely monitoring and diagnosis. Some worrying accompanying signs include:
The anus and surrounding area have pus discharge; Diarrhea with blood; Hemorrhoids protruding; The skin around the anus is dull and abnormally thick.
2. Is it okay to have anal itching after going to the toilet?
Anal itching after defecation often comes from the following two causes:
The anus is not cleaned thoroughly: After defecation, if not cleaned thoroughly, the remaining waste will cause an uncomfortable burning sensation; The anus is not cleaned thoroughly: After defecation, if not cleaned thoroughly, the remaining waste will cause an uncomfortable burning sensation.
Cleaning the anus too vigorously: Rubbing the anus too vigorously after defecation can lead to irritation and itching.; Cleaning the anus too vigorously: Rubbing the anus too vigorously after defecation can lead to irritation and itching.
At this time, changing habits can bring positive improvements. However, if this symptom continues to repeat and becomes more severe, the patient should consult a doctor to detect other medical problems early.
3. Does having anal itching at night mean you have a disease?
Pinworms can cause irritation, making the area around the anus itchy. This type of parasite tends to be more active at night, so this is the time when the itching feeling is most intense.
4. Does anal itching mean hemorrhoids?
Hemorrhoids are one of the common causes of anal itching. However, this is not the only factor. This symptom can also be caused by improper hygiene habits, eating habits, sexual diseases, pinworm infection... In this case, the patient can contact a doctor early for an accurate diagnosis.
5. Is it okay to have anal itching during pregnancy?
During pregnancy, women are likely to experience anal itching because hormones cause veins to dilate. In this case, the patient should discuss carefully with the doctor to have appropriate treatment methods. Do not arbitrarily use medication to avoid affecting health as well as the fetus.
